SHAH AND KRISHNA MURARI, JJ.) BHIMASHANKAR SAHAKARI SAKKARE KARKHANE NIYAMITA Versus WALCHANDNAGAR INDUSTRIES Appellant; LIMITED (WIL) Respondent. Civil Appeal No. 6810 of 2022t , decided on April 10, 2023 A . Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 - S. 34(3) & proviso thereto - Ss. 2(j) & 4 of the Limitation Act, 1963 and S. 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 - Application for setting aside award - Delay - Exclusion of period during which Court is closed - When permissible - When period of 30 days condonable at discretion of the Court under S. 34(3) proviso of the Arbitration Act, or part thereof, falls on holiday or during Court vacation - Benefit of S. 10 of the General Clauses Act and/or S. 4 of the Limitation Act - Entitlement to, if any - Held, benefit of exclusion of period during which Court is closed is available only when application for setting aside award is filed within "prescribed period of limitation" i.e. the period of three months prescribed in the main part of S. 34(3) of the Arbitration Act - The same, held, is not available in respect of period which may be extended by Court in exercise of its discretion under S. 34(3) proviso of the Arbitration Act - Thus, held, S. 4 of the Limitation Act is not at all attracted to facts of present case - S. 10 of the General Clauses Act, held, also not applicable to facts of present case in light of proviso to S. 10 thereof - Period of three months prescribed under S. 34(3) of the 1996 Act expired on 24-11-2016 - Appellant was entitled to a further extended period of 30 days from 23-11-2016 onwards in terms of proviso to S. 34(3) which was up to 24-12-2016 - Trial courts were closed on account of winter/ Christmas vacations from 19-12-2016 to 1-1-2017 - However, it so happened that extendable/condonable period of 30 days as contemplated in proviso to S. 34(3) expired on 24-12-2016 on which day trial court was closed on account of winter/Christmas vacation - Appellant filed application under S . 34 of the 1996 Act, challenging award passed by Arbitral Tribunal - Appellant also filed intervention application for condonation of delay - Both, S . 34 application as well as application for condonation of delay were filed on reopening day i.e. on 2-1-2017 - As application under S. 34 of the 1996 Act was beyond prescribed period provided under main part of S . 34(3) of the 1996 Act as well as beyond condonable period of 30 days, intervention application to condone delay, held, liable to be dismissed as period beyond three months plus 30 days is not condonable as under the 1996 Act, maximum period provided for preferring an application under S. 34 is three months plus 30 days t Arising out of SLP (C) No. 11216 of 2022. Arising from the Judgment and Order in Bhimashankar Sahakari Sakkare Karkhane Niyamita v. Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 - Ss. 34(3) and 43(1) - S. 4 of the Limitation Act, 1963 - Setting aside arbitral award - Application for - Delay condonation - Applicability of the Limitation Act, 1963 - Extent of - Clarified C d - S. 43(1) of the Arbitration Act specifically provides that the Limitation e Act, 1963 shall apply to arbitrations as it applies to proceeding in Court - However, the Limitation Act, 1963 shall be applicable to matters of arbitration covered by the 1996 Act save and except to the extent its applicability has been excluded by virtue of the express provision contained in S. 34(3) of the Arbitration Act - Therefore plea that the Limitation Act is not applicable to proceedings under the Arbitration Act is not tenable - Hence, S. 4 of the f Limitation Act would be applicable - See Shortnote A as to manner in which S. 4 of the Limitation Act would be applicable - Limitation Act, 1963, Ss. 4 and 29(2) As per Section 34(3) of the Arbitration Act, three months are prescribed for preferring an application under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act against the arbitral g award. However, the said period is extendable by a further period of 30 days in terms of the proviso to Section 34(3) of the 1996 Act. In the present case, the period of three months prescribed under Section 34(3) of the Arbitration Act expired on 24-11-2016. The appellant was entitled to a further extended period of 30 days from 23-11-2016 onwards in terms of the proviso to Section 34(3) which was up to 24-12-2016. h ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. The trial courts were closed on account of winter/Christmas vacations from 19-12-2016 to 1-1-2017. However, it so happened that extendable/condonable period of 30 days as contemplated in the proviso to Section 34(3) expired on 24-12-2016 on which day the trial court was closed on account of winter/ Christmas vacation. The appellant herein filed the application under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act, challenging the award passed by the Arbitral Tribunal. The appellant also filed intervention application for condonation of delay. Both, Section 34 of the 1996 Act application as well as the application for condonation of delay were filed on the reopening day i.e. on 2-1-2017. As the application under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act was beyond the prescribed period provided under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act as well as beyond the condonable period of 30 days, the trial court dismissed intervention application and refused to condone the delay by recording finding that the period beyond three months plus thirty days is not condonable as under the Arbitration Act, maximum period provided for preferring an application under Section 34 is three months plus thirty days. Before the High Court, Section 4 of the Limitation Act, 1963 and Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 were pressed into service. By the impugned judgment and order the High Court dismissed the said appeal by recording the finding that the expression "prescribed period" appearing in Section 4 of the Limitation Act cannot be construed to mean anything other than the period of limitation and therefore, any period beyond the prescribed period, during which the Court or Tribunal has the discretion to allow a person to institute the proceeding, cannot be taken to be "prescribed period". Thus, the present appeal in the Supreme Court. The appellant contended that the present case reflects an anomalous situation where Section 4 of the Limitation Act, which only deals with the period of limitation prescribed under the Limitation Act, leaves a vacuum as far as statutory condonable period is concerned. In the case of such statutory condonable periods, Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, which is much wider in its import and applicability, and embodies the same legal principle, must necessarily step in to fill the vacuum . The appellant contended that every consideration of justice and expediency would require that the accepted principle which underlines Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 should be applied in cases where it does not otherwise in terms apply. Further it was contended by the applicant that the litigant has a right to avail limitation up to the last day and his only obligation is to explain his inability to present the suit/petition on the last day of limitation and each day thereafter till it is actually presented. The appellant also contended that reference to Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 in Sagufa Ahmed, (2021) 2 SCC 317 is tangential at best. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Ltd.~cccc® IONLINEf True Prinf 456 SUPREME COURT CASES Dismissing the appeal, the Supreme Court Held: (2023) 8 sec When Section 2(}) of the 1963 Act is read in the context of Section 34(3) of the 1996 Act, it becomes amply clear that the prescribed period for making an application for setting aside an arbitral award is three months. The period of 30 days mentioned in the proviso that follows sub-section (3) of Section 34 of the 1996 Act is not the "period of limitation" and, therefore, not the "prescribed period" for the purposes of making the application for setting aside the arbitral award. The period of 30 days beyond three months which the court may extend on sufficient cause being shown under the proviso appended to sub-section (3) of Section 34 of the 1996 Act being not the "period of limitation" or, in other words, the "prescribed period", Section 4 of the 1963 Act is not, at all, attracted to the facts of the present case. (Paras 51 and 52) Now, so far as the submission on behalf of the appellant that the Limitation Act shall not be applicable to the proceedings under the Arbitration Act is concerned, the aforesaid has no substance. Section 43(1) of the Arbitration Act specifically provides that the Limitation Act, 1963 shall apply to arbitrations as it applies to proceeding in Court. However, as observed and held by the Supreme Court in Assam Urban, (2012) 2 SCC 624, the Limitation Act, 1963 shall be applicable to the matters of arbitration covered by the 1996 Act save and except to the extent its applicability has been excluded by virtue of express provision contained in Section 34(3) of the Arbitration Act. (Paras 54 to 56) Now, so far as reliance placed upon Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 on behalf of the appellant is concerned, at the outset it is required to be noted that such a contention is untenable in light of the proviso to Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, which specifically excludes the application of Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 to any act or proceeding to which the Limitation Act, 1877 applies. Reference to the 1877 Act will now have to be read as reference to the Limitation Act, 1963 in view of Section 8 of the General Clauses Act, 1897. (Para 57) Therefore, in light of the application of the Limitation Act, 1963 to the proceedings under the Arbitration Act and when Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 specifically excludes the applicability of Section 10 to any act or proceeding to which the Limitation Act, 1963 applies and in light of the definition of "period of limitation" as defined under Section 2(}) read with Section 4 of the Limitation Act and as observed and held by the Supreme Court in Assam Urban case, benefit of exclusion of period during which the Court is closed shall be available when the application for setting aside award is filed within "prescribed period of limitation" and shall not be available in respect of period extendable by Court in exercise of its discretion. (Paras 58 to 60) Assam Urban Water Supply & Sewerage Board v. Subash Projects & Mktg. Ltd., (2012) 2 SCC 624 : (2012) 1 SCC (Civ) 831, applied Union of India v. SHAH, J.- Feeling aggrieved and dissatisfied with the impugned judgment and order dated 23-2-20221 passed by the High Court of Karnataka, a at Kalaburagi in Misc. First Appeal No. 201018 of 2018 by which the High Court has dismissed the said appeal and has confirmed the order dated 2-4-2018 passed by the learned Hird Additional District and Sessions Judge, Vijayapur (hereinafter referred to as "the trial court") in rejecting the application for condonation of delay caused in preferring the application under Section 34 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 (hereinafter referred to as "the b Arbitration Act"), the original applicant has preferred the present appeal. 2. The brief facts leading to filing of the present appeal in a nutshell are as under. 3. That, an arbitral award was passed against the appellant under the provisions of the Arbitration Act on 24-8-2016. As per Section 34(3) of the Arbitration Act, 90 days are prescribed for preferring an application under c Section 34 of the Arbitration Act against the arbitral award. However, the said period was extendable by a further period of 30 days in terms of the proviso to Section 34(3) of the Act, 2016. In the present case, the period of 90 days prescribed under Section 34(3) of the Arbitration Act expired on 24-11-2016. The appellant was entitled to a further extended period of 30 days d from 23-11-2016 onwards in terms of the proviso to Section 34(3) which was up to 24-12-2016. 4. The trial courts were closed on account of winter/Christmas vacations from 19-12-2016 to 1-1-2017. However, it so happened that extendable/ condonable period of 30 days as contemplated in the proviso to Section 34(3) expired on 24-12-2016 on which day the trial court was closed on account of winter/Christmas vacation. The appellant herein filed the application under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act, challenging the award passed by the Arbitral Tribunal. The appellant also filed IA No. 1 for condonation of delay. Both, Section 34 application as well as the application for condonation of delay were filed on the reopening day i.e. on 2-1-2017. As the application under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act was beyond the prescribed period of provided under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act as well as beyond the condonable period of 30 days, the learned trial court dismissed IA No. 1 and refused to condone the delay by observing that the period beyond 120 days is not condonable as under the Arbitration Act, maximum period provided for preferring an application under Section 34 is 120 days. 5. At this stage it is required to be noted that in the affidavit filed by the appellant before the High Court, filed in support of IA No. 1, the appellant as such admitted that it received the copy of the award on 24-8-2016. However, according to the appellant, the said award was misplaced and thereafter obtained a fresh copy on 29-12-2016. Shah, J.) in that view of the matter, the period of limitation would commence from 24-8-2016 and 120 days are to be counted from 24-8-2016. 6. Feeling aggrieved and dissatisfied with the order passed by the learned trial court refusing to condone the delay in preferring application under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act, the appellant herein preferred an appeal before the High Court. 7. Before the High Court, Section 4 of the Limitation Act, 1963 and Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 were pressed into service. By the impugned judgment and order the High Court has dismissed 1 the said appeal by observing that the expression "prescribed period" appearing in Section 4 of the Limitation Act cannot be construed to mean anything other than the period of limitation and therefore, any period beyond the prescribed period, during which the Court or Tribunal has the discretion to allow a person to institute the proceeding, cannot be taken to be "prescribed period". 8. Feeling aggrieved and dissatisfied with the impugned judgment and order1 passed by the High Court, the original applicant has preferred the present appeal. 9. Shri Shyam Diwan, learned Senior Advocate has appeared on behalf of the appellant and Shri Dhruv Mehta, learned Senior Advocate has appeared on behalf of the contesting respondent. 10. Shri Shyam Diwan, learned counsel has submitted that Section 34(3) of the Arbitration Act specifies that the limitation period for filing an application for setting aside the arbitral award under Section 34 is three months from the date on which the party making application has received the award. However, if the Court is satisfied that the applicant was prevented by sufficient cause from making the application within the said period of three months, the proviso to the Section specifies a further period of 30 days within which the application under Section 34 may be filed/entertained. 11. It is submitted that the central question in the present petition is whether when the last day of condonable period of 30 days falls on a holiday or during a court vacation, would the benefit of Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 would be available to the appellant? 12. It is submitted that in other words, can the appellant-petitioner file the application on the next date when the Court reopens, in line with the settled principle that the law does not compel a person to do an impossible act. It is submitted that in the present case the appellant-petitioner had filed the application under Section 34 on the very day when the Court reopened. 13. It is submitted by Shri Shyam Diwan, learned Senior Counsel that not extending the benefit of Section 10 of the General Clauses Act to the appellant in such circumstances leads to an anomalous situation wherein the benefit of statutorily prescribed condonable period is cut short for some persons due to l Bhimashankar Sahakari Sakkare Karkhane Niyamita v. It is submitted that this creates uncertainty and unpredictability in the application of provision in question. 14. It is submitted that the present case reflects an anomalous situation where Section 4 of the Limitation Act, which only deals with the period of limitation prescribed under the Limitation Act, leaves a vacuum as far as statutory condonable period is concerned. It is submitted that the judgment in Assam Urban Water Supply & Sewerage Board v. Subash Projects & Mktg. Ltd. 2 failed to take into account that in the case of such statutory condonable periods, Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, which is much wider in its import and applicability, and embodies the same legal principle, must necessarily step in to fill the vacuum. 15. It is submitted that while passing the impugned judgment and order1, the High Court has heavily relied upon the decision of this Court in Assam Urban 2 while holding that the term "prescribed period" referred to in Section 4 of the Limitation Act, 1963 only includes the limitation period and not the 30- day condonable/grace period. It is submitted that however the case of Assam Urban 2 does not notice or deal with Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897. It only notices and deals with Section 4 of the Limitation Act, 1963 and holds that the term "prescribed period" mentioned in Section 4 means the period of limitation. It is submitted that the judgment in Assam Urban 2 fails to notice that Section 4 of the Limitation Act, 1963 which deals with the period of limitation prescribed under the Limitation Act, 1963, leaves a vacuum as far as the statutory condonable period is concerned. 16. It is submitted that in failing to notice Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, the judgment in Assam Urban 2 disregards the principle embodied in the General Clauses Act which is much wider in its import and applicability and must necessarily step in to fill the vacuum left by Section 4 of the Limitation Act. 17. It is further submitted by Shri Diwan, learned Senior Counsel appearing for the appellant that although the same general principle of "elementary justice" is embodied in both Sections of the two Acts, there is a crucial distinction between the Limitation Act, 1963 and the General Clauses Act, 1897. 18. It is submitted that Section 2(j) of the Limitation Act defines "period of limitation". It is submitted that thus, while the term "prescribed period" has a narrower meaning in the context of the Limitation Act, there is no such restrictive definition clause in the General Clauses Act. It is submitted that in fact, the scheme of Section 10 of the General Clauses Act is clear from a bare perusal of the provision and indicates that there are two prescribed periods in this Section viz. (1) the prescribed period within which something is directed 2 (2012) 2 sec 624: (2012) 1 sec (Civ) 831 l Bhimashankar Sahakari Sakkare Karkhane Niyamita v. Shah, J.) to be done, or (2) the prescribed period within which something is allowed to be done. 19. It is submitted that therefore, reading of Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 makes it clear that the period in which something is allowed to be done, such as 30 days' condonable period provided by the proviso to Section 34(3) of the Arbitration Act is also a prescribed period within the meaning of the General Clauses Act, 1897. 20. It is further submitted by Shri Shyam Diwan, learned Senior Counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant that the principle embodied in Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 is an elementary piece of justice. It is submitted that the 60th Law Commission Report on the General Clauses Act reiterated the parliamentary intention behind the Act and the provision, which is to deliver elementary justice. 21. It is submitted that in HUDA v. Babeswar Kanhar3, this Court has observed and held that every consideration of justice and expediency would require that the accepted principle which underlines Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 should be applied in cases where it does not otherwise in terms apply. It is observed that the principles underlying are lex non cogit ad impossibilia (law does not compel a man to do the impossible) and actus curiae neminem gravabit (the act of court shall prejudice no man). It is submitted that in Manohar Joshi v. Nitin Bhaurao Patil4, it is observed and held by this Court that the litigant has a right to avail limitation up to the last day and his only obligation is to explain his inability to present the suit/petition on the last day of limitation and each day thereafter till it is actually presented. 22. Expiry of prescribed period when court is closed.-Where the prescribed period for any suit, appeal or application expires on a day when the court is closed, the suit, appeal or application may be instituted, preferred or made on the day when the court reopens. Explanation.-A court shall be deemed to be closed on any day within the meaning of this section if during any part of its normal working hours it remains closed on that day.' The above Section enables a party to institute a suit, prefer an appeal or make an application on the day the court reopens where the prescribed period for any suit, appeal or application expires on the day when the court is closed. 13. The crucial words in Section 4 of the 1963 Act are "prescribed period". What is the meaning of these words? 14. Section 2(j) of the 1963 Act defines: '2. The period of 30 days mentioned in the proviso that follows sub-section (3) of Section 34 of the 1996 Act is not the "period of limitation" and, therefore, not the "prescribed period" for the purposes of making the application for setting aside the arbitral award. The period of 30 days beyond three months which f the court may extend on sufficient cause being shown under the proviso appended to sub-section (3) of Section 34 of the 1996 Act being not the "period of limitation" or, in other words, the "prescribed period", in our opinion, Section 4 of the 1963 Act is not, at all, attracted to the facts of the present case. 15. Therefore, as such the question involved in the present appeal is squarely answered against the appellant and the said issue is as such not res integra. 54. Now, so far as the submission on behalf of the appellant that the Limitation Act shall not be applicable to the proceedings under the Arbitration Act is concerned, the aforesaid has no substance. Section 43(1) of the Arbitration Act specifically provides that the Limitation Act, 1963 shall apply to arbitrations as it applies to proceeding in Court. However, as observed and held by this Court in Assam Urban 2 , the Limitation Act, 1963 shall be applicable to the matters of arbitration covered by the 1996 Act save and except to the extent its applicability has been excluded by virtue of express provision contained in Section 34(3) of the Arbitration Act. 55. In Popular Construction Co. 8, when Section 5 of the Limitation Act was pressed into service to proceedings under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act for setting aside the arbitral award, this Court has observed that the Arbitration Act being a special law and provides a period of limitation different from that prescribed under the Limitation Act, the period of limitation prescribed under the Arbitration Act shall prevail and shall be applicable and to that extent the Limitation Act shall be excluded. That, thereafter, it is observed and held that application challenging an award filed beyond period mentioned in Section 34(3) of the Arbitration Act would not be an application "in accordance with" sub-section (3) as required under Section 34(1) of the Arbitration Act. 56. In Hindustan Construction Co. 12, in fact this Court has emphasised the mandatory nature of limit to the extension of period provided in the proviso to Section 34(3) and has held that an application for setting aside an arbitral award under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act has to be made within time prescribed under sub-section (3) of Section 34 i.e. within three months and a further period of 30 days on sufficient cause being shown and not thereafter. 57. Now, so far as reliance placed upon Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 on behalf of the appellant is concerned, at the outset it is required to be noted that such a contention is untenable in light of the proviso to Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, which specifically excludes the application of Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 to any act or proceeding to which the Limitation Act, 1877 applies. Reference to the 1877 Act will now have to be read as reference to the Limitation Act, 1963 in view of Section 8 of the General Clauses Act, 1897. 2 Assam Urban Water Supply & Sewerage Board v. Therefore, in light of the application of the Limitation Act, 1963 to the proceedings under the Arbitration Act and when Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 specifically excludes the applicability of Section 10 to any act or proceeding to which Limitation Act, 1963 applies and in light of the definition of "period of limitation" as defined under Section 2U) read with Section 4 of the Limitation Act and as observed and held by this Court in Assam Urban 2 , benefit of exclusion of period during which the Court is closed shall be available when the application for setting aside award is filed within "prescribed period of limitation" and shall not be available in respect of period extendable by Court in exercise of its discretion. 59. Now, so far as the reliance placed upon the decision of this Court in Sridevi Datla v. Union of India 13 relied upon on behalf of the appellant is concerned, at the outset it is required to be noted that in the said decision, this Court has not noticed the decision in Assam Urban 2 and there is no discussion on distinction between "prescribed period" and the "discretionary condonable period". On the other hand, the binding decision of this Court in Assam Urban2 is directly on point. 60. In view of the above and for the reasons stated above, applying the law laid down by this Court in Assam Urban 2 , it cannot be said that the High Court and the learned IIIrd Additional District and Sessions Judge, Vijaypur have committed any error in refusing to condone the delay caused in preferring application under Section 34 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 which was beyond the period prescribed under Section 34(3) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996. 61. Under the circumstances, the present appeal deserves to be dismissed and is, accordingly, dismissed.
